skill.name: operating-k8s-local
skill.description:
Operates local Kubernetes clusters with Minikube for development and testing.
Use when setting up local K8s, deploying applications locally, or debugging K8s issues.
Covers Minikube, kubectl essentials, local image loading, and networking.

security_audit.summary: Documentation skill with a benign verification script. The skill provides Kubernetes commands and YAML examples. The verification script only reads the SKILL.md file to validate structure.

content.value_statement: Managing local Kubernetes clusters for development and testing is complex and error-prone. This skill provides ready-to-use commands for Minikube, kubectl, and Kubernetes manifests to streamline local K8s operations.
actual_capabilities: Start and stop Minikube clusters with custom resources
Enable and configure Kubernetes addons like ingress and metrics-server
Manage kubectl contexts and namespaces for multi-cluster environments
Generate and apply Kubernetes resource manifests (Deployment, Service, ConfigMap, Secret, Ingress)
Debug pods, view logs, and troubleshoot cluster issues
Build and load local Docker images into Minikube
limitations: Requires Minikube, kubectl, and Docker to be installed locally
Does not manage cloud Kubernetes clusters (see deploying-cloud-k8s skill)
Does not provide Helm chart management (see containerizing-applications skill)

prompt_templates.title: Start Minikube
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to start Minikube with 8GB RAM and 4 CPUs, then enable the ingress addon and metrics-server

prompt_templates.title: Deploy Application
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me create a Kubernetes Deployment and Service for my app. Use local Docker images with imagePullPolicy: Never

prompt_templates.title: Debug Pod Issues
prompt_templates.description: My pod is not starting. Show me how to check events, logs, and troubleshoot common issues

prompt_templates.title: Access Services
prompt_templates.prompt: How do I access my application running in Minikube? Show me NodePort and kubectl port-forward options

output_examples.input: Start a Minikube cluster with 8GB RAM and enable ingress
output: ✓ Enable ingress addon: minikube addons enable ingress

best_practices: Use dedicated resources for Minikube to avoid memory pressure on your host machine
Enable metrics-server addon to monitor resource usage with kubectl top
Use local images with imagePullPolicy: Never for faster development cycles
anti_patterns: Running Minikube with default resources when your application needs more memory
Forgetting to enable ingress addon before deploying Ingress resources
Using ClusterIP services without understanding when NodePort or port-forward is needed

faq.question: What drivers does Minikube support?
faq.answer: Minikube supports docker, virtualbox, vmware, hyperkit, and kvm2 drivers depending on your operating system.

faq.question: How do I switch between multiple Minikube clusters?
faq.answer: Use minikube profile <cluster-name> to switch. Run minikube profile list to see all clusters.

faq.question: How do I access the Kubernetes dashboard?
faq.answer: Run minikube addons enable dashboard, then minikube dashboard --url to access it via a URL.

faq.question: Is my data safe when deleting Minikube?
faq.answer: Deleting Minikube removes all cluster data. Use minikube stop to preserve state when not in use.

faq.question: Why are my local images not pulling?
faq.answer: Ensure imagePullPolicy is set to Never and you have run eval $(minikube docker-env) to use Minikube's Docker daemon.

faq.question: How does this differ from cloud Kubernetes?
faq.answer: This skill focuses on local Minikube clusters. For cloud K8s (EKS, GKE, AKS), use the deploying-cloud-k8s skill instead.
